so products that are frequently Co

what do they eventually end up

this information from our product

you know again using machine learning
for that now for the rest of my talk I'm
just going to dive deeper into two
specific topics question answering and
catalog quality both of these are
projects within my team now the
motivation here is that Amazon product
pages contain a wealth of information we
have product descriptions that contain
information about product specifications
like battery life camera megapixels and
so on or we have customer reviews that's
shown here that capture user feedback
and
sentiment about different product
features we also have customer community
QA data you know that contains
authoritative answers to customer
questions these are typically open-ended
questions about people's experience with
using a product or how a product
compares with other products now the
average product page for the top 20
top-selling products across categories
contains about 4,000 words so clearly I
mean finding information can be
difficult and so to make it easy for
users to find information that's
embedded in these different you know
product descriptions customer reviews
and so on we have implemented a
question-answering interface on our
product pages users can type in a
question in that red box there and will
generate an answer many different types
of questions are there so a majority of
product questions are about product
features here you can see the users
asked a question how heavy is it it has
a factoid answer so many of these
questions have factoid answers the
answer here is eight point six ounces
its extracted from the product
description or many of the questions can
have subjective answers that are
available in reviews so for example
here's a question is it expensive and
here's the answer that's sort of
extracted from a customer review for the
price this camera is good value for
money for an amateur photographer now
one thing to see here is that the you
know the snippets that contain answers
to the questions do not have high tech
similarity your high text overlap with
the questions the question here has the
word heavy but the matching snippet with
the answer has the word weight similarly
the question here as the word expensive
and the matching snippet has the word
value for money which again doesn't
overlap so what this means is you need
to do semantic matching between
questions and snippets and then there
are product comparison questions that
compare how two products you know the
compare two products with this
two different features we have product
compatibility questions that are about
how well a pair of products work
together and there are a number of
challenges I'm not going to go through
all of them but in general you know
understanding the semantics of questions
a question like what is ISO refers to
the definition of fire so but if the
customer asked a question what is though
is so just adding the word dub changes
the meaning of this question completely
and it's more about what is the ISO
value of the camera as I mentioned
earlier we need to perform semantic
matching between questions and snippets
and that happens because you can refer
to a product attribute like price in
several different ways
keep inexpensive bang for the buck there
are all these different ways of
referring to the same product attribute
we want to generate natural language
answers all the answers should be
generate should have a very high degree
of precision to maintain customer trust
and of course you know you could get
questions like will this suitcase fill
in the overhead of an airplane now
answering a question like that would
require you to perhaps know the
dimensions of the airplane that won't be
available on your page and I'm not going
to go into details but we use deep
learning and neural networks to learn
these semantics embeddings for questions
and snippets so that similar and
semantically related questions and
snippets have embeddings that are close
by and that allows us to do semantic
matching and we have various loss
functions that we use to optimize these
networks again I'm not going to go into
all the equations and the details but
what we found is on different precision
metrics using our embedding and semantic
approach provides much higher precision
at rank one numbers almost 96 percent
compared to using a baseline that simple
text matching based on cosine similarity
and here are some qualitative results
for a question answering system you can
see for the first four questions the
answers we return are you know
semantically matching there may not be
text matching so for example our

that the keyword basketball is

that we've returned in this snippet
similarly you know the question what is

is it has a snippet which is item

semantically related and our system is
able to
figure out those semantic associations
okay so with that I'm just going to

know we have close to 200 million

interesting information around title
image descriptions and customers place a

consistent and our there's two piece
you know pre-specified guidelines and
now here are some examples of defects
you can see here with our product titles
and you know one thing in our catalog is
it's all all the information is uploaded
by sellers because we are a marketplace
so a third party seller can upload

reasons why some of these product

presumably to get more impressions
you may also could have image defects so
for example here this product image

shows a bag here you know you did a
title says the color of the dress is

placed an order for this product you
wouldn't know whether you're going to

you know extract attributes like brand
color size
from product titles and it's all powered

it's of poor quality
this image contains a color you know a

representations for these different
image classification tasks and once
we've extracted attributes like brand
color category from titles images we can
compare them and detect you know product
